Kmart Opening in the Bronx, And Brooklyn May Be Next
Kmart, the national discount retailer best known for its blue-light specials, plans to open its first store in the Bronx and is considering two locations in Brooklyn.

The Bronx store, a 128,000-square-foot mega-store, is under construction at 300 Baychester Avenue near Co-Op City and is to open on Nov. 25, the day after Thanksgiving, according to Michelle DeLand, a spokeswoman for Kmart.

In Brooklyn, Ms. DeLand said, Kmart is looking around Bensonhurst and also at a site in Park Slope. Kmart has stores in Queens and Staten Island. And the Rest Is History: Landmark Makes a 'Fantastic' Rug Showroom

The New York Bank for Savings building, the striking, copper-domed landmark on the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and 14th Street, has been empty since 1981, when a bank merger closed it. Yesterday, after a two-year renovation, Central Carpet opened its second store at the location. The building, bought by Central Carpet in 1992, was built in 1896 and designated a historical landmark, for its interior and exterior, in 1988.

"It was love at first sight," said Scott Newborn, the general manager. "As you do with a home, there are times when you walk in and you see the furnishing in the space. We instantly pictured it as this fantastic showroom."

The architects, Scarano, Englert & Norton, added a free-standing mezzanine -- avoiding the antique marble walls -- that overlooks the original banking hall. The design incorporated the central Corinthian columns.
Central Carpet plans to display up to 15,000 carpets in the store, making it one of the largest showrooms in the city. Imax in the Evening, or Afternoon, As 3-D Comes to Lincoln Center

Workers are completing the Sony Theaters Lincoln Square complex, a 12-screen movie multiplex that features the world's largest 3-D movie screen, an 80-by-100-foot sheet of vinyl equivalent in height to an eight-story building. The screen will show movies shot with the Imax system, which uses extra-large film frames (up to 10 times the size of standard 35-millimeter film) to create very clear images and depth of field.

The centerpiece of the complex is the 900-seat Loews auditorium. With a crystal chandelier, oversized seats and balcony seating, it is designed to evoke the spirit of the original Loews Theater, a 1930's movie house on West 72d Street. It was demolished in 1961. The Lincoln Square complex, at Broadway and 67th Street, is to open in mid-November.
